document.docAuthor: Suksai, Benjamart, Gustafson, Grey T., Sites, Robert W. & Sangpradub, Narumon
document.masterDocTitle: The Gyrinidae (Coleoptera) fauna of Thailand: Key to tribes and genera, with new records and keys to species of Dineutini and Gyrinini

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Gyrinidae (Coleoptera) fauna of Thailand: Key to tribes and genera, with new records and keys to species of Dineutini and Gyrinini

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Habitus of Gyrinini and Dineutini species: (A)
Gyrinus sericeolimbatus
, dorsal view, female; (B)
G. smaragdinus
, dorsal view, male; (C–D)
Dineutus australis
, dorsal view: (C) male; (D) female; (E)
D. sitesi
, dorsal view, male; (F)
D. spinosus
, dorsal view, male; (G)
D. unidentatus
, dorsal view, male; (H)
Porrorhynchus marginatus
, dorsal view, male; (I)
D. sitesi
, ventral view, male; (J)
D. spinosus
, ventral view, male. Scale bars = 3 mm.

FIGURE 2.
Gyrinus smaragdinus
: (A) female pronotum, median transverse depression (arrow), scale bar = 300 μm; (B) male elytra, spaced puncture (arrow), scale bar = 1 mm; (C) male elytral apex, scale bar = 300 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female: Similar to male but with a more oval body form; gonocoxae as in Fig. 3E .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Aedeagus and gonocoxae: (A–B)
Gyrinus sericeolimbatus
: (A) aedeagus, dorsal view (after Svensson 1991 ; Mazzoldi 2010 ); (B) gonocoxae, ventral view, scale bars = 0.5 mm; (C–E)
Gyrinus smaragdinus
: (C–D) aedeagus, scale bars = 0.5 mm: (C) dorsal view; (D) lateral view; (E) gonocoxae, ventral view, scale bars = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis. Among the Old World
Gyrinus
,
G. smaragdinus
is closest to
G. ignitus Régimbart, 1895
, a Malagasy endemic species. The only other species of
Gyrinus
recorded from Thailand is
G. sericeolimbatus . G. smaragdinus
can be distinguished from
G. sericeolimbatus
by its iridescent appearance and strongly sulcate lateral elytral setriae.

Distribution. This species is known from northeastern India , to Myanmar , Yunnan Province of southern China , and northern Vietnam ( Ochs 1930 ; Vazirani 1972 , 1984 ; Mazzoldi 1995 ). It is here recorded for the first time in Thailand .

Habitat. We found
G. smaragdinus
most often on stagnant water of montane streams and ponds at high elevation, ranging from 700 to 1600 m a.s.l. ( Figs. 7A–B ). Only a few specimens were found in a stream at a low elevation ( 270 m a.s.l.).

Discussion.
G. smaragdinus
is the only species of
Gyrinus
that we encountered during our sampling in the northern, western and northeastern regions of Thailand ( Fig. 8A ). The first author found this beetle in a pond surrounded by land with both agricultural use and intact forest.
